children.title: metals
children.comment: Gold, silver, bronze, iron, copper, tin and lead are all mentioned in Scripture. Prized for their value, they were used in a variety of ways. Scripture uses as an image a metal refiner's fire for the purification of the lives of believers.

children.title: It was an exceptionally heavy metal
Inscriptions were sometimes made on lead

cschildren.title: Idols were often made from various metals
The refining of metals as an image of purification

children.title: minerals
children.comment: Material mined from the earth, especially metal ores and other substances of neither animal nor vegetable origin.

primaryrefs.comment: ``soda'' in this instance is probably sodium carbonate, which would react violently with vinegar.

seealsos.comment: the infant Moses placed in a basket coated with tar

children.title: bronze
children.comment: A metal highly prized for its strength and durability. It had a variety of uses in biblical times and was employed extensively in both the tabernacle and temple.

cschildren.title: Bronze as a material used by craftsmen

children.title: It was renowned for its strength
It was noted for its brilliance
It was less valuable than gold or silver

cschildren.title: Offerings of bronze were made at various times
Bronze was used in the tabernacle

children.title: For the altar and its utensils
For the tent and the framework of the tabernacle

cschildren.title: Bronze was used extensively in the temple

children.title: clay
children.comment: Clay was a basic building material in biblical times and clay pottery was widely used.

children.title: Clay tablets were used for writing on

cschildren.title: Clay was a relatively weak material
Clay was a very common material
God and his people compared to a potter and the clay

children.title: coal
children.comment: Carbonised vegetable material of wood, woody matter or charcoal, used for burning.

cschildren.title: Coal burned in the Most Holy Place
Coal used for baking and cooking
Burning coal associated with divine punishment
Burning coal in descriptions of God

seealsos.comment: Coins of various denominations were made of copper in late OT and in NT times.

children.title: dross
children.comment: Impurities removed from molten metal during refining. In a spiritual sense, wicked people whom God removes in judgment, and also impurities in believers which are removed by discipline and trials.

cschildren.title: God removes the wicked like dross
Dross as a metaphor for impurity in God's people
God purges the dross from his people

children.title: By the blood of Jesus Christ
By the work of the Holy Spirit
glass
children.comment: A substance remarkable for its transparency. Two phenomena seen by John in his vision in the book of Revelation are likened to glass.

cschildren.title: The gold in the new Jerusalem likened to glass

children.title: gold
children.comment: The most valuable of all metals, gold was indicative of wealth and prosperity in biblical times. It had a wide variety of uses and was employed extensively in both the tabernacle and the temple.

seealsos.comment: Wisdom cannot be bought with gold
The streets of the new Jerusalem are to be paved with gold.
Joshua sends the eastern tribes home
the adornments of unfaithful Jerusalem

cschildren.title: Gold was mined from the earth
Gold was presented as offerings to God
Gold was given to rulers as tribute and bribes
The use of gold in the tabernacle

seealsos.comment: the atonement cover and cherubim
the altar

cschildren.title: The use of gold in priestly vestments
The use of gold in the temple

seealsos.comment: used to make the golden calf
used to make Gideon's ephod
Nebuchadnezzar's image of gold

cschildren.title: Metaphorical and proverbial use of gold
Iron ore is mined from the earth
Iron ore is refined by smelting in a furnace

children.title: Such imagery is often used of God's testing of his people
Egypt is described as an iron-smelting furnace

cschildren.title: Iron was prized for its great strength
Iron objects were taken as booty in war
Iron was used in the construction of the temple
Ivory, a semiprecious substance derived from elephant tusks, was procured through trade
Articles inlaid with ivory were a sign of wealth

children.title: jewels
children.comment: Precious stones, prized for their beauty and value are mentioned frequently in Scripture.

cschildren.title: The breastpiece of the high priest was set with twelve jewels
The king of Tyre is depicted as having been adorned with jewels
The new Jerusalem is described as being constructed of jewels
Wisdom is said to be more precious than jewels
The work of other metalworkers and craftsmen
Metal ores and precious stones mined from the earth

children.title: refining
children.comment: The process of heating metals to high temperatures in order to burn away impurities. It is often used in a metaphorical sense to depict God refining his people to get rid of impurities in their faith.

children.title: rock
children.comment: A symbol of strength and permanence and a place where people in danger often took refuge. God is depicted as the Rock of Israel, being the strength, security and deliverance for his people.

cschildren.title: Rock as a symbol of strength, stability and permanence
Rocks as places of refuge and shelter

children.title: Symbolising safety and refuge in him

cschildren.title: Rocks in mining, quarrying and building

children.title: Rocks used to seal caves and tombs

cschildren.title: Rocky soil in the parable of the sower

children.title: salt
children.comment: A basic commodity, used for seasoning and preserving food in biblical times.

cschildren.title: The importance of salt in the sacrificial system

seealsos.comment: The addition of salt to incense was probably to make it burn more easily and quickly

cschildren.title: Believers as the salt of the earth

primaryrefs.comment: This teaching reflects the importance of salt as a preservative and seasoning.

cschildren.title: Salt as a symbol of desolation
Salt sown on arable land to render it worthless
Lot's wife turned into a pillar of salt
The Dead Sea an important source of salt

seealsos.comment: The literal translation of the Hebrew phrase used here is ``... we eat the salt of the palace ...''

primaryrefs.comment: The Dead Sea was known as ``the Salt Sea'' or ``the Sea of the Arabah'' in biblical times.

children.title: sand
children.comment: A fine granular substance formed by the erosion of rocks, and found especially in the deserts and by the sea. It is often used as a symbol of innumerability and occasionally as a symbol of instability.

cschildren.title: Sand as a fine granular substance

children.title: God promised that Israel would be as innumerable as sand
Armies described as being as innumerable as sand
Other comparisons with the innumerability of sand

cschildren.title: The instability and impermanence of sand

children.title: silver
children.comment: A precious metal often surpassed in value only by gold. It had a variety of uses and by NT times was common in coinage.

cschildren.title: Possession of silver a sign of wealth

seealsos.comment: Hezekiah's riches
the adornments of unfaithful Jerusalem

cschildren.title: Silver given as offerings to God
Silver abundant in Jerusalem in Solomon's time

seealsos.comment: the redemption of firstborn males
The rulers of the Philistines offer to pay Delilah for the secret of Samson's great strength
David buys Araunah's threshing-floor and oxen
Haman promises to pay those who destroy the Jews
Judas returns the thirty silver coins
the statue in Nebuchadnezzar's dream
Esteem is better than silver or gold

children.title: stones
children.comment: Pieces of rock, used extensively for building.

seealsos.comment: repairing the temple
rebuilding the temple after the exile
Jesus Christ prophesies the temple's destruction.

children.title: Other references to building with stone

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ described as a stone

children.title: sulphur
children.comment: A yellow, crystalline substance, also known as brimstone, which ignites and burns readily. It is invariably associated with divine punishment in Scripture.

cschildren.title: Divine punishment by means of burning sulphur
Sodom and Gomorrah destroyed by burning sulphur
